I‚Äôve played Rust for over a thousand hours, so take this as a warning, not advice:
Rust isn‚Äôt a game. It‚Äôs a place. And once you land on beach, something in you never leaves.

My first night, I built a small shack‚Äîfour walls, a door, and a campfire. I thought I was safe.
I wasn‚Äôt.
In Rust, ‚Äúsafe‚Äù is just the calm before the storm.

The footsteps came first. Soft. Circling. Eerie.
Then a voice in chat whispered:
‚ÄúNice base you‚Äôve got.‚Äù
I didn‚Äôt sleep much after that.

You learn fast that everyone is either hunter or prey‚Äîand you don‚Äôt get to choose. One morning your base is gone, your loot scattered, and someone‚Äôs left a smiley face sign thanking you for the donation.

You respawn naked.
Again.
And again.
Until you start to change.

You hear phantom footsteps when you‚Äôre offline. You flinch at helicopters. You see a pile of rocks on the roadside and feel the urge to hit them. You judge buildings by whether they‚Äôd survive twelve rockets. Rust rewires you.

And when you log in at 3AM just to ‚Äúcheck the base,‚Äù you finally understand:
You‚Äôre not playing Rust. Rust is playing you.

So if you‚Äôre thinking of starting‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt.
Because once you spawn in, once you swing that first rock, once you hear that distant gunshot echo through the trees...
there‚Äôs no coming back.

The game ‚ÄúRust‚Äù is an absolutely thrilling and addictive survival experience! If you‚Äôre looking for a game that will test your instincts, patience and creativity, you‚Äôre in the right place.

One of Rust‚Äôs biggest strengths is how easy it is to jump into. Even though the world looks harsh and chaotic, you can start playing almost immediately ‚Äì you spawn with a rock, make a fire and begin building your first base. The basics are simple and easy to understand for any newcomer.

And that‚Äôs exactly where the real fun begins.

Rust isn‚Äôt just about staying alive ‚Äì it‚Äôs about building, planning and constantly adapting your strategy. Players create their own bases, gather resources and try to protect their loot from others. And trust me, other players are often the biggest challenge you‚Äôll face.

The ability to build, defend and raid creates endless possibilities ‚Äì from peaceful gathering in the forest to adrenaline-packed raids full of explosions and chaos. Every day is different, every wipe tells a new story, and every encounter can be your last.

If you want a game that feels alive, unpredictable and endlessly replayable, Rust is the perfect choice.

I absolutely love the concept of this game, but recent updates by the developers don't make sense and are lackluster, I believe this game is being mismanaged.

**jungle update**
  - doesn't make sense gameplay-wise, tier 0 biome right next to spawn beach yet has wildly unfair animal AI compared to other biomes
  - doesn't offer any monuments other than ziggarat, it looks cool, but offers almost nothing for the amount of risk you have to go through.
**meta shift**
  - slows down progression (people complained that it's too fast) by adding blueprint fragments to various puzzles
  - kind of works on low pop, a lot of players from my server complain that it's not fun to obtain
  - you will be prim-locked forever as a solo / small team on high pop.
  - fragments serve no purpose afterwards if you already have the corresponding workbench
  - imo they tackled the wrong thing, they should've done something about unlocks, not workbenches
**pivot or die**
  - made tech tree costs stupidly low (why? didn't you just slow down progression?)
  - removed workbench taxes by default (this is something that i believe should've been experimented with, reward players for finding items in-world with noticeable cost reductions, rather than completely locking them out of workbenches and then suddenly making lucky players with workbenches be able to progress at mach 4)
**naval update**
  - not out, but so far from staging branch seems like it'll have the same issue like the jungle biome where there's not enough value for the amount of effort and risk you have to go through to reach and stay afloat in the deep sea

it just seems like they're changing stuff just for the sake of change and that they've ran out of ideas. although i've never played during this era, i believe that rust's content updates had more vision under Garry's leadership. every update served a purpose whereas a lot of newer updates under Alistair's leadership don't add anything interesting or even actively harm the game. there's also been a lot more focus on monetization to the point where I feel like I'm playing a F2P game, P2W items exist, they allow you to do things normal players can't do, there is literally a hazmat that changes stats for money. servers owners also lose a lot of control over their own servers with new EULA changes, you cannot even the odds between players by giving P2W items in any way (loot tables, ability to craft, etc) as a server owner, you cannot restrict players with P2W items from using them for any reason at all either, it's not a good look and just sucks for people who dislike having to spend money on microtransactions to compete on a game that's they've already paid for.

optimization is also another issue, it uses an absurd amount of VRAM (6GB for eighth resolution, which is the lowest graphics preset) for a game that doesn't look as good as others which consume less memory, this could be a unity limitation for all i know but this is absurd and it was never this bad when i played a year ago. it also uses a ton of memory in general and 16GBs is not something you should be playing with. recent updates have also added a lot of buggy code and constant client errors which aren't seemingly being addressed.

i also want to express my concerns about Linux support, as it would be really nice if you allowed EAC to work under Proton, it's a single checkbox that you can tick in the EOS dashboard and shipping linux EAC binaries. I know it's weaker but would it be that bad considering that most servers already moderate suspicious players? Rust (The Game): Brutal, Beautiful, and Unforgettable

Rust isn't just a game; it's a social experiment disguised as a survival simulator. From the moment you wake up naked on the beach, armed with nothing but a rock and a healthy sense of paranoia, the experience is relentlessly intense and deeply rewarding. This is a game built entirely around high-risk, high-reward gameplay, and it delivers adrenaline in spades.

The high tension is constant. Every action carries weight: punching a tree, gathering stone, or even just sprinting across an open field. You are never safe. The distant sound of gunfire or the metallic clank of an enemy base door triggers an immediate, visceral fear. There‚Äôs nothing quite like the feeling of watching the clock tick down at 3 AM, waiting for your furnace to finish smelting high-quality metal, knowing that an entire server group might be preparing for a raid.

This leads directly into the late nights. Time management is often tossed out the window in favor of survival. "I'll just farm for 15 more minutes," quickly turns into the sun rising as you frantically repair bullet holes in your outer walls after a four-hour siege. The peak tension comes during base defense or offense‚Äîa successful raid or a defended base at 4 AM is an unforgettable rush that leaves your hands shaking and your head buzzing.

The depth of building, crafting, and community interaction (whether friendly or hostile) ensures there‚Äôs always a new goal to chase. If you crave a game that is difficult, challenging, and offers some of the most heart-pounding moments in gaming today, Rust is the ultimate experience.

I was very late to Rust, only getting this game in 2025 because I'd recently been itching for an online survival game with an apocalyptic feel. I have no idea why I avoided it for so long, but here are my thoughts.

Solo: Good luck playing this game solo. You'll need either very good people skills on the right server or you'll have to be incredibly good at staying out of sight. The solo life in Rust is a unique one full of frustration. As it should be!

Team: This is where Rust is at its absolute best, and where I sank over 100 hours into it during my first two weeks this past summer (2025). Battling other groups on the server is so much fun; the game quickly developed a The Walking Dead vibe for me, minus the zombies. The core gameplay is great, base building with a team is rewarding, and even the exploration mixed with encountering other players' bases has been a fantastic experience.

This game is NOT for everybody, which is a main reason my total hours are low (no friends to play with). I don't have many friends who can handle the toxic environment Rust features. You will die, you will lose your loot, and you will be unfairly treated by others. If you're not a fan of that, this is not your game.

Rust provided everything I want in a PVP survival game, and once I have the right team assembled, I will absolutely be back in.

I've played this game on and off for many years and overall, I love it. I do have some positive and not as positive things to say about the current state of the game though

Positives: I love the game style, offering PvP and PvE content on different servers. This versatility is probably one of my most favorite thing about this game however the graphics have improved greatly over the years. Most holiday events are self explanatory to complete and the rewards are fairly good. The purchasable skins are also something I enjoy adding, and the cost of the items are reasonable, including purchases on the marketplace. Creatures in the game are challenging at the beginning of the wipe but once geared, are quite easy to defeat. Monuments are fun to explore and offer many hiding spots while participating in PvP. Over the years, they have added quite a bit of content and though I took breaks throughout the years, I would give Rust an overall positive rating. The environment is beautiful and the things they've done to improve the look has been phenomenal. On smaller servers, I've had the opportunity to create lifelong friends in other parts of the world, so I'd have to say this is probably my top favorite thing about this game.

Negatives: I believe too much has been added to the game and somewhat takes away from the original vanilla Rust from the mid 2010s. Some items have been nerfed quite a bit so it makes game play quite different while also giving larger groups advantages that smaller groups or solo players may not have. For new players, this makes the game undesirable. Friends I've invited to play Rust with me have stopped playing for this reason. Why play a game that's impossible to learn while getting defeated within minutes at respawn? Playing on a PvE server can be fun, but doesn't quite offer the challenges that a PvP server has. The addition of blueprints has been something that I believe would have been good in theory, but in practice offers larger groups to benefit from right out the gate. I understand the point of teaming up in a PvP environment, but there is no benefit to playing on a large server as a solo or even a small team for the first time. An issue I've experienced is sometimes while dismounting a horse, you'll get stuck or kicked for anticlip if the horse is beside another one at the trough. This is one of a few issues I've seen which I expected would've been fixed by now, but it still seems to be an issue. 

If you can ignore the negatives I've stated above, I still recommend this game. I play as often as possible and I've been playing again now for about a year. I've been officially playing Rust since about 2015 and it is still my favorite game despite the things I've listed as negatives. Happy hunting!

Rust has for many years been my favourite game and over those many years the reason why has changed.

Initially I was curious because I saw a Youtuber named Vertiigo playing the game and thought the game looked nice, the mechanics were well thought out and the player interactions were quality.

The game is constantly being updated, changed, added to and re-balanced. 

There is a wide variety to the styles of servers available to play on. 
The PVP servers have no shortage of players willing to go to any lengths to make a play. The combat is intense and exciting. The rewards are satisfying. 
The PVE server user community have a depth of creativity and game knowledge that I have rarely seen on other games. From people constructing amazing bases to using the full scope of the inter-connectivity between the items you can deploy, You will see it all on PVE.

The game is mature in dev cycle and content. 
This is not a game for kids or people who are emotionally fragile, naive or easily triggered.
You are likely to witness the full spectrum of gamer words.

There are numerous skins, DLC packs and plugins that enhance and extend game play in ways you would not expect to work so well. 
If you have ever wanted to stream MIDI to the in game piano you are playing then Rust has you covered. 

I hope you enjoy the game as much as I have.

Rust is a game that stands out not simply as a survival adventure, but as a living, breathing social ecosystem that shapes itself around those who step inside it. Developed by Facepunch Studios, Rust places players in a harsh, unpredictable world where the only goal is to survive. However, the beauty of the game lies far beyond gathering materials or crafting better tools. Rust explores the complexity of human behavior, trust, betrayal, power, and community, creating an experience that is both thrilling and deeply meaningful.

The game begins in one of the most humble ways imaginable. You spawn on a shore or in a field with nothing but a rock and a torch. You have no armor, no shelter, and no direction. The world is vast and indifferent to your presence. The forests whisper with danger, the landscapes stretch endlessly, and every resource must be earned. This starting point is essential to Rust‚Äôs identity. When you eventually build a working base, gather advanced tools, or craft powerful weapons, you feel a sense of pride because you remember when you had nothing. Every step forward is something you fought for.

Crafting and progression in Rust unfold naturally and reward persistence. You gather wood, stone, and metal, progressing from simple tools to firearms and fortified bases. The systems are balanced in a way that makes even the smallest accomplishment feel valuable. But while the environment shapes your journey, it is other players who define your story. Rust is famous‚Äîsome would say infamous‚Äîfor its player-driven interaction. There are no NPCs to rely on, no safe zones guaranteed, and no rules forced upon the world. The true danger and excitement come from those sharing the server with you.

Every encounter with another player comes with weight. Will they greet you with friendliness or hostility? Will you trade supplies, share a campfire, or end up fighting to the death? Because Rust does not predetermine behavior, the community creates its own moral code. Alliances form, tribes expand, betrayals unfold, wars erupt, and diplomacy is negotiated‚Äîall naturally, without scripts or missions. This makes every server feel like an ongoing story written collectively by everyone playing.

One of the most captivating aspects of Rust is the emotional investment it inspires. Because you spend hours gathering resources, designing your base, and protecting your gear, the risk of loss creates true tension. Venturing outside your walls means accepting the possibility that everything could be taken from you. This tension makes moments of success exhilarating. Winning a raid after a carefully planned attack, or defending your base from enemies while your team coordinates under pressure, are moments of adrenaline that few games can replicate. Losses hurt, but victories feel unforgettable.

Visually, Rust is stunning in its realistic simplicity. The world feels rugged and real, with weather that shifts from peaceful sunsets to harsh storms that hammer the land. The sound design deepens the immersion‚Äîchains clanking, footsteps crunching on snow, or distant gunfire echoing through the hills all enhance the intensity and atmosphere. The environment is not just something you look at‚Äîit is something you feel.

As Rust has evolved, updates have introduced new monuments, vehicles, building tools, and quality-of-life improvements. Yet the heart of the game remains the same: it is a world where you shape your fate. Every player creates their own narrative. Some become architects of towering fortresses, some become merchants trading goods, some become nomads moving place to place, and some become warlords ruling the server with force and fear. Rust gives you the freedom to be whoever you choose to be.

In the end, Rust is not just a survival game‚Äîit is a psychological sandbox where creativity, intelligence, and emotion all collide. It challenges players not only to build and fight, but to think, adapt, trust, and negotiate. The memories it creates are real because they are formed through genuine effort, struggle, and interaction with others.

For those who seek a game with depth, excitement, unpredictability, and stories that feel truly personal, Rust is nothing less than extraordinary. It is harsh, it is intense, and it is unforgettable‚Äîexactly what a survival game should be.

Jumping into Rust feels like being dropped into a post-apocalyptic Hunger Games with no rules and no mercy. You wake up naked on a beach, armed with nothing but a rock and a torch. From there, it‚Äôs up to you to survive, build, and dominate or get dominated. And trust me, the learning curve is steep, but the payoff is wild.

At its core, Rust is a PvP-heavy survival game where everything is player-driven. You gather resources, craft tools, build bases, and raid others. But what makes it truly special is the social gameplay. Every encounter with another player is a gamble. Will they help you? Rob you? Shoot you on sight? That tension never goes away, and it‚Äôs what keeps the game so addictive.

The building system is deep and flexible. You can create anything from a humble shack to a fortress with traps, turrets, and hidden loot rooms. But no base is truly safe, raiding is a core part of the game, and defending your turf becomes a full-time job. The monthly ‚Äúforce wipe‚Äù system resets all progress, keeping the meta fresh and giving everyone a chance to start over.

Combat is fast and unforgiving. Guns feel punchy, and there‚Äôs a real skill gap when it comes to aiming and movement. Whether you‚Äôre sniping from a tower or ambushing someone with a shotgun, fights are intense and often over in seconds. And if you die? You lose everything. That risk makes every decision matter.

Rust‚Äôs world is harsh but beautiful. The map is procedurally generated, with monuments like abandoned labs, oil rigs, and military tunnels offering high-tier loot and danger. You‚Äôll need to balance exploration with caution‚Äîsome areas are crawling with NPCs or rival players.

It‚Äôs not all doom and gloom, though. There‚Äôs a thriving community of roleplayers, builders, and chill farmers who just want to vibe. Servers range from hardcore PvP to relaxed modded worlds, so you can find your niche. And the modding scene is huge, custom maps, skins, and plugins keep things fresh.

That said, Rust is not for the faint of heart. It‚Äôs toxic at times, full of griefers, and can be incredibly frustrating. But if you embrace the chaos, it‚Äôs one of the most rewarding and memorable multiplayer experiences out there.

Whether you‚Äôre solo sneaking through the woods or rolling deep with a clan, Rust will test your patience, your strategy, and your ability to survive when everything‚Äôs stacked against you.

I get that wipes keep the servers fresh and prevent dominance by long-time players, but it often feels like a punch in the gut, especially for casual players who can't grind as hard. It discourages long-term creativity and makes progress feel temporary.

On the flip side, I'd love to see the Facepunch team expand the tech tree with more innovative gadgets and features. Things like advanced automated defenses, or new high-tech devices (e.g., drones for scouting or solar-powered traps) could add fresh layers to base-building and strategy. The game already has some cool tech elements, but introducing novel items would keep the meta evolving and give players more ways to experiment without relying solely on guns and explosives.

Despite the wipe frustration, Rust is still a solid 9/10 for me. If you're into intense multiplayer survival with a mix of cooperation and betrayal, it's worth diving in‚Äîjust be prepared to start over now and then.

With how rust has been designed, and especially recently, the game has come to be a cesspool for groups of people that live in echo chambers bent on the misery of others. Cheaters, toxic clans, hell even roofcampers. There are your occasional pockets of light, your Willjum-esque players, or the man himself. But the game is designed for groups to shit on solos. It is very difficult to progress with the compounding nature of rust's basis for success. Resources, base sizes, and pvp in general make for very difficult progression when you only have so much time, effort, or general manpower. 

With the old system, scrap was the grinding resource for progression. Raiding was something you could do throughout, and you can always progress with your level of destruction with that scrap, making big groups capable of getting large amounts of scrap with general monument runs, excavator, etc and then progressing quickly through the tree by having a single person use the workbench to research the biggest things/everything, designating them the crafting person or the like. 

With the new system, progressing via Blueprint fragments (Gatherable from relatively rare/fought over military crates, dropped (extremely rarely) by scientists, and from 'guaranteed' drop rooms you need keycards from other areas to access. 
The issues that arise from this new system are primarily that they dont fix the issues from the old systems, they are an attempt to fix the symptom of a problem that is basically insolvable. The reason they made this change was because it "detracted from world PvP especially in and around monuments." The reason pvp doesn't happen at monuments is because of Gear Fear, and the lack of need to go into the monuments for anyone other than the most savvy of players. This update makes going to monuments 
'basically' mandatory as you need blueprint fragments to upgrade your workbench and progress. The update originally only had the fragments attainable from the keycard rooms, which was such a bad change they had to alter it immediately. I'll get to why I don't think that this is a good move in a second.

The new system provides a requirement for the threat of pvp. The issue with this is, that the ability for a player TO pvp is only so valuable in a game as punishing as rust is. Multiple players, duos, trios, groups of 4 or even more dominate this game a lot, and it makes the lifestyle of a solo player non-optimal if you want any kind of engaging gameplay that doesn't just feel like repeated resource runs for 5+ hours. 

Because that's what the game boils down to if you're solo. Run for sulfur, run road for scientists, check the closest monument for a military crate, recycle your stuff, and craft stuff, and usually die during one of those first 4 things on a higher population server. But of those things, the monuments are the highest possibility of death. You are far less likely to die doing road runs or mining sulfur than you are in a monument or recycling.

On lower pop servers, you're lucky to have people interact with you at all unless you build right next to them. I saw bases be built, get raided, and decay without interacting with their owner or the raiders a single time. I fished for most of my scrap, which I genuinely feel saved me a lot of time, easily getting 500+ per 20-30 minute run. But in that time I only interacted with 1 group of other players, on their way to do a monument run. The players I did end up pvping were mostly passing through, or at a gas station/supermarket recycler I was trying to use, and rarely ended up being anything truly fruitful, never got any fragments or good gear sets from a friggin recycle run.

And the reason this makes for bad design as i mentioned earlier is because of the assumption that players, especially solos, will go for the method that guarantees them a spawn, I.E the keycard rooms or military crates. And in that way what you have to realize is that, gamers will engineer the fun out of a game. They will make it as efficient as possible to get as much gain as possible, and its the job of the developer to prevent that from happening by adding road blocks within the systems. 

They have since added a new road block by making it so you need to get blueprint fragments, but that isn't roadblocking the right things. World pvp doesn't happen because people don't want to lose their gear. Fight the SOURCE of that problem, not the symptom of it. But by making this new roadblock you have forced players to find a solution, and guess what the most efficient way to get other players fragments is?

If you guessed steal them, what i've been alluding to this whole time, you're correct! I got all my fragments from offline raiding. There's no need for pvp, no need to go into a monument, just mine sulfur, build beancans, build satchels, and raid. Super safe!
I'm sure bigger groups will be progressing similarly enough to their old ways, underwater labs or military tunnels or something, but why bother with that when i can molotov through a door and steal the 1 fragment my neighbor got last night while I was asleep? Especially because the 20+ scientists I killed didn't fuckin drop any!

Blueprint fragments are a solution to a problem that this game cannot fundamentally fix without a big alteration to its design, or safe boxes, or some kind of system in place that enables some kind of player safety and are in fact a detriment to the solo player experience. A solo player is basically never going to get 5 advanced blueprint fragments without tons of relatively boring effort. Metal detecting is extremely slow, having done at least 2 hours of metal detecting and finding 0 fragments. And diving sites are extremely dangerous, with sharks taking 4+ or even MORE spears from a speargun to kill, something a solo will inevitably die from said shark before being able to land a shot. That is effort that I don't want to invest into a game where it will ask me to farm for ANOTHER 30-40 hours trying to get a tier 3 workbench so i can even fucking COMPETE in the echelon the game is asking me to participate in after day fucking 2. Especially when half of that was just mining sulfur.
